conclusion: To determine whether the distance fallen during the 0 to 10 seconds interval is greater than 100 meters or less than 100 meters, we need to analyze the velocity-time graph.
The graph shows the velocity (v) as a function of time (t).
The area under the velocity-time graph gives the distance traveled.
For the time interval from 0 to 10 seconds, the graph is a curve that starts at the origin and increases to a maximum velocity of 20 m/s at t = 10 seconds.
The area under the curve from 0 to 10 seconds can be approximated by the area of a triangle and a trapezoid.
The area of the triangle formed by the velocity-time graph from 0 to 10 seconds is given by: Area of the triangle = (1/2) × base × height.
Here, the base is the time interval, which is 10 seconds, and the height is the maximum velocity, which is 20 m/s.
The area of the triangle is calculated as (1/2) × 10 × 20 = 100 meters.
The area under the curve from 0 to 10 seconds is exactly 100 meters.
The distance fallen during the 0 to 10 seconds interval is equal to 100 meters.
